item.name: Authentication

request.description:
Register a new user account.

**Password Requirements:**
- At least 8 characters
- At least one uppercase letter
- At least one lowercase letter
- At least one digit
- At least one special character (@$!%*?&)

**Returns:**
- Access token (JWT, 1 hour expiry)
- Refresh token (JWT, 7 days expiry)
- User information

Login with email and password.

**Security Features:**
- Account locks after 5 failed login attempts
- Failed attempts are reset on successful login
- Last login time is tracked

**Returns:**
- Access token (JWT, 1 hour expiry)
- Refresh token (JWT, 7 days expiry)
- User information

Refresh access token using a valid refresh token.

Use this when the access token expires (after 1 hour) to get a new one without requiring the user to login again.

**Returns:**
- New access token
- Same refresh token (still valid)
- User information

Logout by revoking the refresh token.

This invalidates the refresh token so it cannot be used to obtain new access tokens. The current access token remains valid until it expires.

**Best Practice:**
- Clear tokens from client storage
- Revoke refresh token on server

Get current authenticated user information.

Requires a valid access token in the Authorization header.

**Returns:**
- User ID
- Email
- Username
- Full name
- Email verification status
- Account creation date

item.description:
User authentication endpoints including registration, login, token refresh, logout, and user profile retrieval.

**Authentication Flow:**
1. Register or Login to get access and refresh tokens
2. Use access token in Authorization header for protected endpoints
3. When access token expires (1 hour), use refresh token to get a new one
4. Refresh tokens are valid for 7 days

**Token Format:**
All requests to protected endpoints must include:
```
Authorization: Bearer <access_token>
```

Fetches repositories accessible to the authenticated user from their GitHub account.

**Requires:**
- User must be authenticated (Bearer token)
- User must have an active GitHub connection (OAuth completed)

**Filters:**
- Only returns repositories where user has push or admin access
- Sorted by most recently updated
- Includes personal repos, org repos, and repos where user is a collaborator

**Returns:**
- Array of repositories with:
  - `full_name`: Repository in "owner/repo" format
  - `description`: Repository description
  - `private`: Whether the repository is private
  - `html_url`: GitHub URL to the repository

**Error Responses:**
- 401: User not authenticated or GitHub token expired
- 404: No GitHub connection found (need to connect GitHub first)
- 500: GitHub API error

**Usage:**
This endpoint is used by the frontend to populate repository dropdowns when configuring GitHub triggers and actions.

item.name: Direct API Tests
Trigger Tests

request.description:
**Test Gmail Email Trigger (Read-Only)**

Checks if the Gmail trigger would fire based on the provided filters.

**Endpoint:** `POST /api/test/trigger/gmail/email_received`

**Request Body:**
- `serviceConnectionId` (required): Your Gmail connection ID
- `gmailLabel`: Gmail label to filter (INBOX, IMPORTANT, etc.)
- `gmailSubjectContains`: Filter by subject keyword
- `gmailFromAddress`: Filter by sender email

**Response:**
- `triggered`: Whether the trigger would fire
- `message`: Human-readable explanation
- `contextData`: Variables that would be passed to reactions
- `itemCount`: Number of matching emails

**Note:** This does NOT execute any reactions - it only checks the trigger condition.

**Test GitHub Issue Trigger (Read-Only)**

Checks if the GitHub issue trigger would fire for the specified repository.

**Endpoint:** `POST /api/test/trigger/github/issue_created`

**Request Body:**
- `serviceConnectionId` (required): Your GitHub connection ID
- `githubRepository` (required): Repository to check (format: owner/repo)

**Response:**
- `triggered`: Whether new issues were found
- `message`: Human-readable explanation
- `contextData`: Issue details (issueNumber, issueTitle, issueAuthor, issueUrl, etc.)
- `itemCount`: Number of new issues

**Note:** This does NOT execute any reactions - it only checks for new issues.

**Test GitHub PR Trigger (Read-Only)**

Checks if the GitHub pull request trigger would fire for the specified repository.

**Endpoint:** `POST /api/test/trigger/github/pr_created`

**Request Body:**
- `serviceConnectionId` (required): Your GitHub connection ID
- `githubRepository` (required): Repository to check (format: owner/repo)

**Response:**
- `triggered`: Whether new PRs were found
- `message`: Human-readable explanation
- `contextData`: PR details (prNumber, prTitle, prAuthor, prUrl, prSourceBranch, prTargetBranch, etc.)
- `itemCount`: Number of new pull requests

**Note:** This does NOT execute any reactions - it only checks for new PRs.

item.description:
**Trigger Test Endpoints (Read-Only)**

These endpoints test if a trigger condition would fire without executing any reactions.

Use these to:
- Verify your service connections work
- Test filter configurations
- Preview what context data reactions would receive

item.name: Reaction Tests

request.description:
**Test Discord Reaction (Executes Action)**

⚠️ **WARNING:** This ACTUALLY SENDS a message to Discord!

**Endpoint:** `POST /api/test/reaction/discord/send_webhook`

**Request Body:**
- `serviceConnectionId` (required): Your Discord connection ID
- `discordChannelId` (required): Target channel ID
- `discordMessageTemplate`: Message with placeholders ({from}, {subject}, etc.)
- `mockContextData`: Simulated trigger context for placeholder substitution

**Placeholders Available:**
- `{from}`, `{subject}`, `{snippet}` - Email context
- `{issueNumber}`, `{issueTitle}`, `{issueAuthor}` - GitHub issue context
- `{prNumber}`, `{prTitle}`, `{prAuthor}` - GitHub PR context

**Response:**
- `success`: Whether the message was sent
- `message`: Result description
- `resultData`: Execution details

**Test GitHub Create Issue Reaction (Executes Action)**

⚠️ **WARNING:** This ACTUALLY CREATES an issue in GitHub!

**Endpoint:** `POST /api/test/reaction/github/create_issue`

**Request Body:**
- `serviceConnectionId` (required): Your GitHub connection ID
- `githubRepository` (required): Target repository (format: owner/repo)
- `githubIssueTitle` (required): Issue title (supports placeholders)
- `githubIssueBody`: Issue description (supports placeholders)
- `githubIssueLabels`: Comma-separated labels (e.g., "bug,urgent")
- `mockContextData`: Simulated trigger context for placeholder substitution

**Response:**
- `success`: Whether the issue was created
- `message`: Result description
- `resultData`: Created issue details

request.description:
**Test GitHub Create PR Reaction (Executes Action)**

⚠️ **WARNING:** This ACTUALLY CREATES a pull request in GitHub!

**Endpoint:** `POST /api/test/reaction/github/create_pr`

**Request Body:**
- `serviceConnectionId` (required): Your GitHub connection ID
- `githubRepository` (required): Target repository (format: owner/repo)
- `githubPrTitle` (required): PR title (supports placeholders)
- `githubPrBody`: PR description (supports placeholders)
- `githubSourceBranch` (required): New branch name for the PR
- `githubTargetBranch`: Target branch (defaults to 'main')
- `githubCommitMessage`: Commit message
- `githubFilePath` (required): Path for new file
- `githubFileContent`: Content to write to file
- `mockContextData`: Simulated trigger context

**Workflow:**
1. Creates new branch from target
2. Commits file with content
3. Opens PR from source to target

**Response:**
- `success`: Whether the PR was created
- `message`: Result description
- `resultData`: Created PR details

item.description:
**Reaction Test Endpoints (Execute Actions)**

⚠️ **WARNING:** These endpoints ACTUALLY EXECUTE reactions!

Use these to:
- Verify reaction configurations work
- Test message templates with mock data
- Debug integration issues

**mockContextData** allows you to provide fake trigger context for testing placeholders.

**Direct API Test Endpoints**

These endpoints allow you to test individual triggers and reactions via the `/api/test/*` endpoints.

**Trigger Tests** (Read-Only):
- Check if triggers would fire
- Preview context data
- No side effects

**Reaction Tests** (Execute Actions):
- Actually perform the reaction
- Send real messages/create real issues
- Use mockContextData for placeholder testing

item.name: Reaction Testing
Discord Reactions

request.description:
Creates a test workflow with Discord 'Send Message' reaction.

**Reaction Type:** `discord.send_webhook` (mode: send_message)

**Configuration Options:**
- `webhookUrl` (required): Discord webhook URL
- `messageTemplate`: Custom message with variable placeholders
- `channelName`: Channel name for reference

**Supported Placeholders:**
- `{subject}`, `{from}`, `{snippet}` - Gmail context
- `{issueTitle}`, `{issueNumber}`, `{issueAuthor}` - GitHub issue context
- `{prTitle}`, `{prNumber}`, `{prAuthor}` - GitHub PR context

Creates a test workflow with Discord 'Send Rich Embed' reaction.

**Reaction Type:** `discord.send_webhook` (mode: rich_embed)

**Configuration Options:**
- `webhookUrl` (required): Discord webhook URL
- `embedMode`: Set to true for rich embed format
- `channelName`: Channel name for reference

**Auto-formatted Fields:**
- Title: Email subject
- Author: Sender email
- Description: Email snippet
- Color: Based on message type

Creates a test workflow with Discord 'Send Batch Notification' reaction.

**Reaction Type:** `discord.send_webhook` (mode: batch)

**Configuration Options:**
- `webhookUrl` (required): Discord webhook URL
- `batchMode`: Set to true for batch notifications
- `maxEmailsToShow`: Max emails to display (default: 5)

**Output Format:**
Summarizes multiple emails in a single notification with count and list.
